greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Numbers m such that the set {1..m} has only one nontrivial decomposition into subsets with equal element sum.
comment: Numbers m such that m*(m+1)/2 has exactly two divisors >= m.
Also numbers m such that m*(m+1)/2 is the product of two primes.
link: T. D. Noe and Alois P. Heinz, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000 (first 1000 terms from T. D. Noe)
example: 10 is in the sequence, because there is only one nontrivial decomposition of {1..10} into subsets with equal element sum: {1,10}, {2,9}, {3,8}, {4,7}, {5,6}; 11|55.
maple: a:= proc(n) option remember; local k;
mathematica: Select[Range@1304, PrimeOmega[#] + PrimeOmega[# + 1] == 3 &] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Jun 28 2010 and updated Sep 21 2018 *)
program: (PARI) is(n)=if(isprime(n),bigomega(n+1)==2, isprime(n+1) && bigomega(n)==2) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Sep 08 2015
results.author: _Alois P. Heinz_, Sep 03 2009
